abstract.p: Ontology matching, aimed at finding semantically related entities from different ontologies, plays an important role in establishing interoperation among Semantic Web applications. Recently, many similarity measures have been proposed to explore the lexical, structural or semantic features of ontologies. However, a key problem is how to integrate various similarities automatically. In this paper, we define a novel metric termed a “differentor” to assess the probability that a similarity measure can find the one-to-one mappings between two ontologies at the entity level, and use it to integrate different similarity measures. The proposed approach can assign weights automatically to each pair of entities from different ontologies without any prior knowledge, and the aggregation task is accomplished based on these weights. The proposed approach has been tested on OAEI2010 benchmarks for evaluation. The experimental results show that the differentor can reflect the performance of individual similarity measures, and a differentor-based aggregation strategy outperforms other existing aggregation strategies.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Ontology is a formal, explicit specification of a shared conceptualization [1], which is increasingly being utilized in various applications for sharing knowledge and interoperating in many domains [2–4]. However, it is not realistic to have a single ontology describing the whole universe. In fact, ontologies developed by different enterprises and institutes are usually so heterogeneous in their names, structures and semantics that they impede interoperation and sharing between ontology-based applications. For example, ontology OS might use Reference to denote the citation of a source information in a book, whereas ontology OT uses another word, Entry, to represent the same thing. Ontology-based applications have to harmonize these heterogeneous ontologies to achieve semantic interoperability, and to share knowledge. Ontology matching, which aims at finding semantic correspondences (equivalence, subsumption, disjoint) between entities (concept, relation, and instance) of different ontologies [5], is regarded as a promising way to solve the problem.

Nowadays, considerable effort has been put into the development of ontology-matching methods with various techniques [5–8]. Linguistic-based approaches process the lexical information by constructing virtual documents [9,10] or using external resources [11]. Graph-matching techniques convert ontologies into graphs, and match the graphs [12–14]. Machine learning techniques are also utilized for ontology matching [15] by using the instances of ontologies. It has been accepted that combining multiple similarity measures is a promising technique to obtain more accurate results than just using one similarity measure at a time [5]. Most recently, proposed methods have taken advantage of integrating multiple similarity measures as well, for exploring different ontology features (e.g. descriptive information, ontological structures, or instances) simultaneously. For these methods, a critical point is how to integrate these different similarity measures automatically according to different tasks.

Weighting is the most popular similarity aggregation method for integrating multiple similarities. The weight is assigned to a particular similarity measure, and can be obtained by machine learning techniques, or can be predefined manually. For the method based on machine learning techniques, rich data are acquired to train the algorithm for obtaining weights, which are not easily obtained in real applications. However, weights assigned for similarity measures manually by experience are not adaptive to different matching tasks. Therefore some ontology-matching systems try to assign the optimal weights for different similarity measures automatically. In the field of schema matching, SMB [16] is proposed, based on the AdaBoost algorithm, to select matches automatically and tune their importance. In the field of ontology matching, RiMOM [17] and UFOme [27] use the linguistic and structural information encoded in the ontologies to determine weights for linguistic and structural similarity measures respectively. However, these systems need to count the identical labels or structures between two ontologies to obtain the corresponding weights before matching the ontologies. This is a time-consuming task, and in some cases the cost of counting made matching nearly impossible. One of state-of-the-art similarity aggregation strategy is that proposed by Mao et al. [10]. This method defines a metric called “harmony” as the reliability with which an unambiguous one-to-one mapping can be found, based on a specific similarity matrix. It assigns the harmony values to each similarity measure as the weight in the aggregation, so that the weights of different similarity matrices can be automatically tuned. Based on the harmony method, the weights of similarity measures can be assigned according to their reliability.

All the methods mentioned above assign only one fixed weight for a similarity measure in similarity aggregation. We argue that a similarity measure performs differently under different conditions: that is, some entities can be handled well by a similarity measure whereas others may not. For example, if some entities have the same labels or missing labels, a lexical measure based on labels will not perform well on them, but may perform well on other entities, as shown in Figure 1 (CompositeT and BookT in OT both have the same labels). If we can assign higher weights for a similarity measure to the entities it handles well, and lower weights to the entities it tackles poorly, the aggregation of various similarity measures should give better results. Motivated by this observation, in this paper we propose a novel differentor-based similarity aggregation strategy that automatically determines one weight for each similarity measure on different entity pairs, depending on the similarity matrix. We implemented this aggregation strategy in a prototype system, and compared it with some well-known similarity aggregation strategies. For evaluating the proposed aggregation approach, we adopted the OAEI2010 benchmark tests and followed their evaluation metrics, calculating precision, recall and F-measure for each test, against a reference alignment. The experimental results show that:

list-item.p: the differentor does reflect the performance of its corresponding similarity measure;
the differentor-based similarity aggregation strategy performs better than other strategies on the OAEI2010 benchmarks;
the implemented prototype system based on the differentor performs well, even using simple similarity measures.

sec.p: The rest of this paper is organized as follows. Section 2 gives the problem statement and some definitions in ontology matching. Some related work in terms of similarity aggregation strategy is described in Section 3. In Section 4, we illustrate some simple similarity measures to calculate various similarities from different features of ontology, and show how to aggregate these similarities and extract alignments. The experimental results and the comparison with other similarity aggregation strategies are described in Section 5. Section 6 gives a brief conclusion.

sec.title: 3. Related work
sec.p: Currently, there are many ontology-matching systems, as surveyed by Euzenat and Shvaiko [5] and Choi et al. [7]. Various kinds of information provided in ontologies are exploited in these systems. To aggregate the similarities obtained by different similarity measures, various similarity aggregation strategies have been proposed. In the following, we review only some ontology-matching systems that are most related to our work.

COMA [27] is a generic schema-matching system. It exploits Max, Min, Average and Weighted strategies for the aggregation. The Weighted strategy assigns a relative weight to each individual similarity measure, and computes a weighted sum of similarity for all similarity measures. Average is a special case of Weighted, which considers each similarity equally important in the aggregation. Max and Min are two extreme cases, which return the highest and lowest similarities in all similarity measures respectively.

FOAM [18] uses the ordered weighted average (OWA) to aggregate the values obtained by individual similarity measures; this is a kind of ontology-independent aggregation function. In this case, a weight used by the OWA operator is not associated with a specific similarity measure, but instead with a specific ordered position. From this point of view, FOAM can assign weights to the entity level. It adopts linguistic quantifiers [19] to determine OWA weights. Six kinds of OWA operator –Max, Min, Average, Most, At least half (Alh) and As many as possible– are exploited to aggregate different similarities. Meanwhile, the semantic interpretations of the six OWA operators are given. In the paper, the Alh operator is the best for aggregating similarities in its evaluation on OAEI benchmarks.

RiMOM integrates multiple linguistic-based (edit distance, vector distance) and structure-based (similarity flooding algorithm) alignment strategies dynamically according to the linguistic and structural features of ontologies. The similarity aggregation function in RiMOM is ontology-dependent. The information of input ontology used in the similarity aggregation includes entities’ labels and structures. It first defines two similarity factors, based on a label similarity factor and a structure similarity factor, and then uses a weighted average to combine the linguistic similarities determined by the two similarity factors. Moreover, a sigmoid function is utilized for emphasizing high similarity and de-emphasizing low similarity in the aggregation. Compared with this, our approach is independent of the characteristics of ontologies. Furthermore, it assigns weight for each pair of entities based on the differentor in similarity aggregation, rather than a fixed weight for a similarity measure.

Prior [10] integrates three IR-based similarity measures to match ontologies based on their linguistic and structural characteristics. This proposes the harmony metric as an estimation of the reliability of finding unambiguous one-to-one mappings in a similarity matrix, and aggregates different similarities based on the metric. In addition, an IAC network that makes use of the constraints in ontology is applied to improve the matching results, if necessary. This system can automatically assign weights for different similarity measures based on their corresponding similarity matrices: that is, it adopts an ontology-independent similarity aggregation function.

ASMOV [20] iteratively calculates the similarity between two entities by exploring their lexical information, structural information and instance data. It combines different matches by using a weighted sum strategy, which adjusts weights empirically, or based on some static rules. At the end of each iteration, a semantic verification technique is used to eliminate invalid mappings by analysing semantic inconsistencies and incompleteness among pre-alignments. However, ASMOV cannot automatically combine different similarities according to different matching tasks.

Compared with the systems mentioned above, the proposed approach assigns weights at the entity level by defining the differentor, and it does not use any information encoded in ontologies in the aggregation. The detail of comparison is shown in Table 1.

sec.title: 4. Differentor-based similarity aggregation
sec.p: Figure 2 gives an overview of the proposed approach, which is implemented under a generic similarity-based ontology-matching framework. First, we utilize the Jena1 API to parse ontologies and normalize all descriptive information of entities by tokenizing and removing stop words. For example, in Figure 1, the comment of Reference is transformed into {base, class, entries} after being preprocessed. Second, we calculate four kinds of similarity for concepts and relations. Specifically, four basic lexical similarity measures are designed, based on the descriptive information (id, label, comment and hierarchy) of entities. One structural similarity measure is designed for matching concepts according to the number of restrictions on their related relations. In addition, instances of concepts are also used to measure the similarity of their corresponding concepts. For matching relations, a semantic similarity measure is proposed, based on the domain and range of relations. As the domain and range are usually composed of concepts (the range can be literals), we match them based on the results of concept matching obtained by the previous similarity measures. In other words, concept and relation are matched separately. Third, we calculate the differentor for each row in each similarity matrix and adaptively aggregate various similarity matrices according to their corresponding differentors. Finally, the alignment is extracted from the normalized similarity matrix with a naive descendant extraction algorithm, introduced by Meilicke and Stuckenschmidt [21].

sec.title: 4.2.1. Definition of differentor
sec.p: In the proposed approach, each similarity measure produces a similarity matrix. The row and column of a similarity matrix are composed of the entities coming from the source ontology and the entities coming from the target ontology, respectively. To combine these similarity matrices to form a final similarity matrix, we propose a metric termed a differentor to evaluate the probability of a similarity measure (or matcher) to find the optimal one-to-one mapping for the entity in a similarity matrix. At the very beginning, it motivated us that the similarity score of two entities mapped in the ground truth should be the highest in a row of a similarity matrix. On the other hand, it is accepted that one similarity measure may work not well for all entities in the ontologies. For instance in Table 2, using Simstructure cannot distinguish between alignments <CollectionS, CollectionT, =, 0.5> and <CollectionS, MonographyT, =, 0.5>, as CollectionS, CollectionT and MonographyT have the same structures in OS and OT. However, it works well for other entities. Inspired by this phenomenon, if we can assign high weights for the entities a similarity handles well and low weights for the entities it handles badly when aggregating similarities, we should obtain a better result. To achieve this goal, we have proposed the differentor metric to reflect the performance of a similarity measure on the level of entities.

sec.title: 4.3. Differentor-based similarity aggregation
sec.p: Aggregating different similarities is pervasive in ontology-mapping systems that contain multiple individual matchers. Many strategies have been proposed to aggregate different similarities. According to the information used in the aggregation, they can be divided into two kinds, as described in Section 2. In this paper, we focus only on ontology-independent functions. A harmony-based strategy assigns weights adaptively for each individual measure according to the characteristics of the similarity matrices (i.e., the number of cells with maximum values in their corresponding row and column). Average-based and max-based strategies assign fixed weights to them, which is not suitable for different matching tasks. A sigmoid strategy emphasizes high individual similarities and de-emphasizes low individual similarities in similarity aggregation. Ahl is a kind of OWA operator utilized in FOAM, which considers only the first half of the similarity values after reordering them in descending order, and performs best in FOAM [18].

Based on the differentor, we propose a novel strategy to adaptively aggregate different similarities, which is an ontology-independent similarity aggregation function. In the proposed method, the probability of finding the optimal one-to-one mappings in a row of a similarity matrix is determined by its corresponding differentor. Therefore it is reasonable to regard the differentor as the weight for its corresponding row in similarity aggregation. From this point of view, the differentor can assign a weight for a similarity measure in the level of entity other than only a fixed weight for the measure. Consequently, for a similarity matrix, it usually has different weights for different rows. For the example in Table 2, the weights for each row in the matrix are 1.0, 1.0, 1.0, 0.5, and 0.67 in similarity aggregation respectively. In detail, the differentor-based similarity aggregation follows the steps below to aggregate various similarity matrices.

list-item.p: Calculate the differentor for each row in all similarity matrices.
Multiply the similarities in each row by their corresponding differentor for each similarity matrix.
Add all similarity matrices to form a final similarity matrix M.
Normalize the similarities in M.

sec.title: 4.4. Alignment extraction
sec.p: After similarity aggregation, we obtain a final similarity matrix M. The next task is to extract alignment from M. Each cell in M can be regarded as a candidate correspondence (its corresponding row and column represent eS and eT respectively, and the value it contains represents the similarity between eS and eT). We adopt a naïve descending extraction (NDE) algorithm [21] to extract mappings based on M. It is a widely used kind of alignment extraction algorithm, which tries to find a correspondence for each pair of entities M. Specifically, it first sorts all cells in descending order according to their similarity values, and then adds the cell with the maximum similarity value into a list L (by choosing the cells with the maximum similarity value in matrix M). Second, all cells (i.e., cells that contain the same source or target concept) contradicted by the chosen ones in L are removed (by setting the corresponding row and column to zero in matrix M). The above steps iterate until no cell with similarity value greater than 0 remains.

Considering the normalized matrix M in Figure 3 as an example, NDE algorithm extracts alignment based on it as depicted in Figure 4 (1)–(7). The extracted alignment includes five correspondences: <Reference, Entry>, <Book, Composite>, < Proceedings, Proceedings>, <Monograph, Monography> and <Collection, Collection>. Hereto, we have accomplished the task of ontology matching between OS and OT.

sec.title: 5.1. Data sets and evaluation metrics
sec.p: We have implemented the proposed approach in Java, and evaluated it on the OAEI2010 benchmarks dataset. The benchmarks include one source ontology and hundreds of target ontologies that can be divided into three subsets according to the information changed in the target ontologies, i.e., 101–104, 201–266, and 301–304. The ontologies in the first group have lexical and structural information similar to that of the source ontology, except for 102, which is an irrelevant ontology. The ontologies in the second group change in lexical, structural or individual information. In particular, some target ontologies are changed so heavily in lexicons that they contain only random strings, or in structure that they become flattened. The ontologies in the third group come from four real-world bibliographic ontologies developed by various organizations. In the experiments, we test the approach on all the groups.

We follow the evaluation metrics from the OAEI contest, that is, the precision, recall and F-measure for each benchmark test. For aggregation of the metrics, the weighted harmonic means [25] are computed. Let C be a set of computed correspondences and Ref be a set of reference correspondences. sec.title: 5.2. Experimental results
sec.p: In the experiments, we wanted to test, first, whether the differentor could reflect the performance of the individual similarity measures. Second, we assessed the performances of different similarity measures and the differentor-based similarity aggregation approach. Third, we compared six similarity aggregation strategies implemented under the generic ontology-matching framework. Finally, we compared the differentor-based ontology-matching approach with other top-performing systems on the recent OAEI2010 benchmarks. In all experiments, the naïve descending extraction algorithm is utilized to extract all alignments.

sec.title: 5.2.1. Correlations between differentors and F-measures of individual similarities
sec.p: The differentor can be regarded as the probability of finding the optimal one-to-one mappings for an entity with a specific similarity measure. We therefore need to evaluate whether the differentor can reflect the performance of a similarity measure for matching ontologies. If we employ only one similarity measure to match ontologies, only the rows whose differentor = 1.0 are selected by using the NDE algorithm to extract alignments. Therefore we define a coefficient named ratio as an overall measure to test the correlation between differentor and F-measures. Here, rowsd means that the number of rows whose differentor = 1.0, and Mrow represents the number of rows in a similarity matrix M. According to the definition of the differentor, we conclude that the greater the ratio is, the better the similarity measure should perform.

Therefore we evaluate the correlation between the ratio and F-measures of a similarity measure on all benchmark tests. As concepts and relations are matched separately in the proposed approach, we test the correlations between the ratio and the F-measure of a similarity measure for concepts and relations respectively. Specifically, for each benchmark test, three kinds of similarity are calculated for concepts (lexical, structural and extensional) and two kinds of similarity for relations (lexical and semantic).

Figure 5(a)–(e) shows the correlations between the ratios and F-measures of Simnaming, Simcomment, Simneighbor, Simstructure and Simextension respectively. For all the tests, the ratios and the F-measures nearly coincide with each other (i.e., they show very similar trends on all tests). Specifically, when the F-measures are high, as in many tests, the ratios are also relatively high. Analogously, when a similarity measure works badly for some tests, the corresponding ratios are also relatively low. For example, as the linguistic information (including naming information and comment) varies greatly in tests 202 and 248–266, the performances of Simnaming on these tests are very poor, and the corresponding ratios are all nearly zero. That is to say, the ratio does reflect the performance of the corresponding similarity measure. The Pearson correlation coefficients between ratios and F-measures for Simnaming, Simcomment, Simneighbor, Simstructure and Simextension are 0.973, 0.999, 0.913, 0.956 and 0.995 respectively.

We also evaluate the correlations between the ratios and F-measures of relation similarity measures. It is worthwhile that the relations are matched based on the results of concept matching. Figure 5(f)–(h) depicts very similar situations to those in Figure 5(a)–(e). The ratios also correlate linearly with the F-measures of both lexical measures and semantic measures, and the Pearson correlation coefficients are 0.993 (Simnaming), 1.0 (Simcomment) and 0.99 (SimRS) respectively.

The high correlations between ratios and F-measures demonstrate that the differentors do reflect the performance of a specific similarity measure. Using differentors as weights for rows in similarity matrices, different similarity measures can be integrated adaptively according to their performance in entity levels, which is very useful and beneficial for aggregation strategy. Another observation from Figure 5 is that the various different similarity measures could complement each other on the test. For example, in Figure 5 the lexical measures find no mappings in tests 248–266, whereas the extensional measure and structural measure perform relatively well. Analogously, the performances of extensional measure in tests 101–221 are not good, whereas the lexical measures work really well. This phenomenon is another consideration that inspired us to integrate different similarity measures according to their performances.

sec.title: 5.2.2. Performance of differentor-based aggregation strategy
sec.p: We test the performances of individual similarity measures first, and assess the performance of the differentor-based aggregation approach at the same time. It is worth noting that the performances are obtained on concept matching, as relations are matched based on the result of concept matching.

Figure 6 compares the performances (i.e. F-measures) of individual similarity measures and the differentor-based aggregation strategy on the OAEI benchmark tests. The differentor-based approach achieves better overall performance than any single similarity measure, except for tests 238, 247 and 304. In test 238, as the concept hierarchy is expanded (by adding more concepts into the ontology and arranging them in the concept hierarchy of the ontology), the proposed approach performs rather poorly compared with naming-base measure. For example, the added concept “ScientificMeeting” is arranged as parent of “Conference”, and the property restrictions that originally belonged to “Conference” are also removed to “ScientificMeeting”. Therefore the proposed approach yields “Conference” and “ScientificMeeting” as a correspondence, whereas the naming-based measure, which is based only on the naming information, is not affected by this change. The same situation also occurs in test 247. In the real world ontology tests (tests 301–304), both descriptive information and structural information vary greatly compared with the reference ontology, which may confuse the individual similarity measures. For example, in Figure 1, the actual mapped pair is <BookS, BookT>, whereas the structure-based and naming-based measures suggest <BookS, CompositeT> as a mapping, because of their similar structures and labels.

caption.p: Comparison of F-measure of each similarity measure and differentor-based measure on each benchmark test.

sec.p: To sum up, although there is some decrease in performance (tests 238, 247 and 304), the differentor-based similarity aggregation approach can greatly improve the overall performance by adaptively integrating individual similarity measures.

sec.p: Our proposed approach assigns a differentor as the weight for each row in the similarity matrix according to the probability of the similarity measure’s finding the optimal mapping in the row. This difference makes the proposed approach outperform other strategies, as shown in Table 4. A concrete example is shown in the following.

caption.p: Comparison of different similarity aggregation strategies

sec.p: Example. Taking matching tests 101 and 302 as an example, as the comment, neighbour and extension similarities for <BookS, BookT> and <BookletS, BookT> are both zero, we give only the naming similarity and structure similarity for them (the maximum values), as shown in Figure 7.

caption.p: Segments of similarity matrices for ontologies 101 and 302.

sec.p: By assigning weights at the entity level, the differentor-based strategy will operate the following steps to aggregate similarities.

list-item.p: It calculates differentors for each row. In the example, the differentors for BooletS = 1.0 and BookS = 1.0 in matrix Mnaming, and BooletS = 0.23 and BookS = 1.0 in matrix Mstructure.
It aggregates similarities. Sim(BooletS, BookT) = (1.0 × 0.84 + 0.23 × 1.0)/2 = 0.535; Sim(BookS, BookT)= (1.0 × 1.0 + 1.0 × 0.2)/2 = 0.6.
OWA-Alh based strategy assigns weights for each position for the similarity array.
It reorders all the similarity values in descending order. For BookletS and BookT, it generates {1.0, 0.84} and similarly {1.0, 0.2} for BookS and BookT.
It assigns weights for each position. By using the equations in Table 3, we get Sim(BooletS, BookT) = (2/5) × 1.0 + (2/5) × 0.84 = 0.736; Sim(BookS, BookT) = (2/5) × 1.0 + (2/5) × 0.2 = 0.48.
The harmony-based strategy considers the harmony of a similarity matrix as its weight in the aggregation.
It calculates the harmony of each similarity matrix. In our experiments, the harmonies of matrix Mnaming and matrix MStructure are 0.39 and 0.33 respectively.
Assigning weights for each matrix would obtain Sim(BooletS, BookT) = (0.36 × 0.84 + 0.31 × 0.74)/2 = 0.305 and Sim(BookS, BookT) =(0.36 × 1.0 + 0.31 × 0.2)/2 = 0.21.
The average-based strategy considers that each similarity measure contributes equally in the aggregation.
Assigning equivalent weights for each similarity measure generates Sim(BooletS, BookT) = 1/5 × 0.84 + 1/5 × 1.0 = 0.368 and Sim(BookS, BookT) = 1/5 × 1.0 + 1/5 × 0.2 = 0.24.
The sigmoid-based strategy emphasizes the high values and de-emphasizes the low values at the same time.
Simnaming(BooletS, BookT) = 0.846; Simstructural(BooletS, BookT) = 0.924; Simnaming(BookS, BookT) = 0.924; Simstructural(BookS, BookT) = 0.182.
Combining the above similarities generates Sim(BooletS, BookT) = (0.846 + 0.924)/5 = 0.354 and Sim(BookS, BookT) = (0.924 + 0.182)/2 = 0.221.
The max-based strategy functions similarly to the sigmoid strategy except that it smooths the similarity values.
Selecting only the entity pairs with maximum similarity values generates Sim(BooletS, BookT) = 1.0 and Sim(BookS, BookT) = 1.0.

sec.p: The truly mapped pair is <BookS, BookT> against the reference alignments. Using the same NDE algorithm to extract alignments for the six strategies mentioned above, the differentor-based strategy suggests <BookS, BookT> as a mapping, whereas the harmony-based, OWA-Alh-based, sigmoid-based and average-based strategies all recommend <BookletS, BookT> as a mapping. As the max-based strategy cannot identify which pair is the right one (having the same similarity value 1.0), it produces no result. In a word, the overall performance of our proposed approach and its performance on real-world ontologies demonstrate that the differentor-based similarity aggregation strategy is effective in ontology matching.

sec.title: 5.2.4. Comparison with other systems
sec.p: Although the implemented system does not participate in the official evaluation contest of OAEI, we provide our results for comparison with other systems that participated using the same evaluation metrics. Only the top five systems in the OAEI2010 [25] and OAEI2011 benchmarks are compared. In the OAEI2011 benchmarks [26], newly generated data sets (benchmark2 and benchmark3), are introduced to evaluate all participating systems. Benchmark2 is available after the preliminary evaluation of OAEI, whereas benchmark3 is not openly available.

Table 5 shows the harmonic means of precision, recall and F-measure to give an overview of the comparison. ASMOV, RiMOM and AgrMaker are the top three systems in OAEI2010 with respect to the harmonic mean of F-measure. The proposed approach provides competitive performance and outperforms all other systems except the top three ones. It is worth noting that we use just some simple and straightforward similarity measures; no tuning algorithms are used in the implemented system. Although the approach is outperformed by ASMOV, RiMOM and AgrMaker, there is no great difference between it and others. The maximum difference between our system and the top system, ASMOV, is 0.069 for H(F). The proposed approach performs well on the new benchmark2, which may benefit from the differentor similarity aggregation strategy. It outperforms other systems slightly in recall, and has a good precision. Despite these good results on benchmarks, there much room for improvement in the performance of the proposed approach. For instance, the current alignment extraction algorithm selects only the maximum ones in the final similarity matrix. That is to say, although the similarities in some rows are very small, we have to choose mappings in these rows according to the alignment extraction algorithm. In a word, it can be seen that it is worth using the differentor to aggregate the different similarities from Tables 4 and 5.

caption.p: Comparison with top five systems based on benchmarks in OAEI2010 and OAEI2011

sec.title: 6. Conclusions and future work
sec.p: In this paper, we focus on solving a subproblem in ontology matching – how to aggregate automatically the different similarities obtained by various similarity measures. A new similarity aggregation strategy is proposed, and a prototype system based on the strategy is also implemented. Four kinds of simple similarity measure are designed for matching concept and relation according to their respective features in ontology. Specifically, all the information directly related to an entity is considered in the similarity calculation. Lexical, structural, extensional and domain/range information embodied in the ontology are considered in similarity computing. To aggregate the different similarities, a metric termed the differentor is proposed, which evaluates the probability of find one-to-one mappings for a similarity measure in the rows of its corresponding similarity matrix. By using the differentor, the strategy can automatically assign different weights adaptively for different entity pairs in similarity aggregation. Finally, the naïve descending extraction algorithm is employed to extract alignments for simplicity. The following conclusions can be drawn from the experiments:

list-item.p: The differentor can reflect the performance of a specific similarity measure to find the one-to-one mappings.

The differentor-based similarity aggregation strategy can adaptively aggregate different similarity measures to take advantage of the complements among them, and achieve better matching results than other well-known similarity aggregation strategies.

The proposed approach performs well on the OAEI2010 and OAEI2011 benchmarks. Additionally, as the differentor-based similarity aggregation is ontology-independent (i.e., it aggregate different similarities based only on the similarity matrices), the proposed approach may find wide application in ontology matching and other related fields. There are some efforts to be made in future work. First, more complex similarity measures are planned to be integrated into the approach, to improve the matching results. Second, we intend to improve the naïve descending extraction algorithm by using some proper thresholds to improve its performance.
